text: this presentation is delivered by the stanford center for professional
development welcome to the stanford seminar in people computers and design uh next week
we are on thanksgiving break and so there will be no talk we'll resume in two weeks today we have james landay and uh
james has had a really fantastic career to date and i wanted to share with you two
reasons why i think his career has been particularly impactful one of them is that so james got his phd from carnegie
mellon in 1996 and he was one of the first technical people in the hci community
to really champion design he's been an early and persistent champion of the role of design and human computer
interaction and in bringing it into the fold for the field and in teaching its methods and he's had
a huge influence there another thing to know about james is that the number of students who he's
advised who have gone on to do all sorts of cool things some of them are are you know slackers
like me but many of the students have gone on and done great things uh including faculty positions at a wide
variety of universities and leading industrial research positions and a bunch of other stuff and
i think that what's remarkable is that many of his former students are doing really different stuff and so it's not like he
built 10 clones of himself but he's figured out how to
foster a community that really helps people find their own way and succeed for
themselves and watching that community continue to grow and blossom has been extremely cool and now he's going to
tell you about his next biggest venture which is world
lab yeah i mean really what scott says academia it's really about the students
and i've been really lucky to work with them lots of really really really great uh smart students but just great people
like scott and jeff and many others what i want to talk about today is
what scott said world lab and i'm going to talk about design and i'm going to talk about technology
um but one thing you might not know about me i was a professor at berkeley and then
i've been at the university of washington for 10 years including a stint running an industrial research lab there for intel
um i spent almost three years over the last four years in china my family and i went and lived in
beijing took a sabbatical that just kind of kept extending you know something nice about the university they say i'm going
to stay away a little while and that time in china was really important for me
culturally important for me with respect to my career important for my family because right
now in china it's a really exciting time you really feel it in the people that they see it's
an important time in their history politically economically socially
but china also has a 5 000 year history of civilization and it was interesting to me to see how
people actually take stories and idioms from that history and use it in their
everyday thinking and and speech and so i'm going to start out with a story for you from china
and use this as part of my talk so what you see here is this bronze
galloping horse this is a horse that was
made in solid bronze it's 2 000 years old from the han dynasty it was only uncovered in 1969 in the
west of china and it's actually an important cultural symbol it's the official symbol of tourism china
but what's really interesting is when they discovered this in 1969 it took several years
for the experts who were baffled as to how was this cast in solid bronze such that it didn't
topple over because what we see here is the legend of this heaven steed was that the horses was so
fast in the west of china that it literally flew and so this horse all the hooves are in the air
except for this one hoof here and it's a little hard to see that is actually stampeding on a swallow that is flying
and looking up in horror as this kind of flying horse is coming by and so it actually baffled the experts
of how did this person cast this and solve bronze as to not fall over and so in
some ways this horse represents balance to me
it represents balance between the beauty of the artistry of the horse and between
that design and artistry of that and the technology to somehow calculate where the center of mass would be so it wouldn't fall over and in
fact the center of mass is in in the in the swallow there at the bottom
and i actually think finding this balance between design and technology hey eric
welcome is is is a really important theme in terms of the kind of technologies
that we design and build today finding this balance between them taking advantage of our skills
on both sides is what leads to new technologies that are desirable so we really need to find this balance
between for example human centered approaches that we get from design and human computer interaction
and more technology centered approaches from computer science and kind of bring those together and even within subfields like human
computer interaction i feel like we need to find a balance between careful controlled experiments
of slightly new things that we invent versus creating brand new systems that just totally
change the world in new ways that we can't necessarily control that easily and experiment with and we need to do
both kinds of work and i'm going to try to talk about some of this as i go forward my time in china also leads me to
believe that we can actually find value by finding balance between different cultures
and different ways of thinking for example this very collective culture that we see in eastern cultures versus the more
individualistic culture we see from the west and that by seeing things from different perspectives that actually leads us
to more creativity and new solutions to problems that we might be attacking so balance is really key in this way
so in the rest of the talk i want to discuss three big problem areas that i think we
as a field should really be working on and how looking at them in this balanced
approach between design technology and also in some instances between cultures can lead us to interesting new solutions
so i'm going to start out first talking about a balance between us as humans in our environment here you
see lake mead which is expected to drop below its intake pipes in the next few years
now you might just say hey don't build cities in the desert kind of stupid um you know la
phoenix vegas but the fact is 36 u.s states
are expected to have major water shortage problems over the next five years and global warming is going to cause this to be more and
more common in many places across the world we've obviously seen these issues in africa and other places for a long time one thing i didn't know
um you know and this is just being kind of you know as an american we're very inward looking
going to live in china was that china has really kind of faced this same kind
of issue for 50 or 100 years in that a lot of the population in china lives in northern china
which is very arid and dry and in fact when i was in beijing they were
literally trucking snow and melting it in the middle of winter to get water for beijing that there's such a severe water
shortage beijing is pretty much a desert okay now um in china they're actually
building one of the largest engineering projects ever which is essentially to move the water from the three major
rivers in the south to the north okay this is like a hundred year project in fact
mal first proposed that i think in 1952 construction started in 2002 and i think
the first big part of it is coming online just around now and it will continue for another 40
years or so and as part of that project millions and millions of people are
displaced from their homes there's huge environmental consequences of that project and so we might think
about you know what are things that we might do in our own lives that might lead us to not
have such water shortages or use that resource better so that maybe we don't need
projects like that so when i try to think of areas like this
i want to think as a researcher to think what would it be a big audacious goal you know as a not
just for my research group but as a field what is something that we could try um to really achieve so in this area we
might say could we cut a family's energy and water use
in a significant way let's say by 50 now you might say hey give me a million dollars i can build you a house off the
grid and you know gets its own water and energy but let's say we said you know for five or ten thousand dollars could we
take existing families homes and um how they use transportation etc the solutions to
these kind of problems i think are going to involve policy you know for example we put higher taxes on gasoline it's going to
change you know how people drive or if we require higher mileage standards that's going to have impact so there's
always policy and planning issues that come into this um but from what we do here in this room
i think can we think of technologies that might help with this as well as design and changing people's
behavior that might have impact in these problem areas so i'm going to focus on that design and
technology because those are the types of things that we do so for example one of the projects
that we've done at the university watch washington is called hydrosense this was a work really led by my
colleague schwedek patel working with another colleague james fogerty and grad student who was leading
a lot of this was john fralick who was working with me and john is now professor university of maryland
and really the key insight that they had was you can think of your pipe your pipe network in your home as an
information network and by carefully sensing changes in the pressure through that
those pipes you could actually sense very inexpensively any valve opening or closing in in that
network and tell what faucets being used in your home and you could also get a pretty good estimate for the volume of water used
now this is kind of cool because you can do it with a really inexpensive sensor that might cost you know 20 or 30
dollars and in fact they did a startup and got bought by belkin who makes all these iphone and other stuff
and it's going to be available in your store you know any any month now supposedly before christmas but maybe
it's gonna fall in the first quarter and get one of these maybe for a hundred dollars one sensor
really inexpensively be able to tell us that's the cool technology for me as an hci person more of my
interest was well what do we do with the design how do we use that information in a way where we might be
able to change people's actual behavior and just to give you a better idea here
here's how it works in terms of the valves opening closing just at the high level the key thing to understand is
this is someone opening a faucet here at the top the middle is a toilet um running and the bottom is a tub
filling and the key is just to see that those waveforms look different you know even the open faucet and the closed faucet look
different and the toilet opened the tub open so you can imagine with some basic signal processing machine learning
you can learn these different patterns and be able to detect it and in fact they get you know in the neighborhood of 95 to 98
accuracy depending on how well you want to know exactly where in the home versus the type of faucet and hot versus cold
if you have two of these you get like 99 accuracy so for me the question was
design and in some ways um this is a lot of what john
focused on at the end of his dissertation was how might we use that information to change behavior and i put this slide in the other day
because i um i like to use in my undergraduate class these kind of hall of fame hall of shame
examples and what i have is always the smart fridge i'm kind of like who wants a smart fridge and i was finding like wait the smart fridge i can
actually use a display in that thing for something useful for one so you could imagine maybe in some high traffic place in your home
maybe it's the fridge maybe it's on some counter that you have some display that you look at it on a regular basis
and it shows you kind of your water use and then the key is how do you design that in a way that would cause behavior change so actually john
led a team and literally looked at dozens and dozens of different design ideas
that look at different design dimensions in this area and did this very extensive online study of something
like 800 people to look at how they understood these dimensions and then we did some in lab
studies with people and then in some in-home studies to understand where they would place this technology and so in this
talk i'm just going to show you a couple of the examples that i think are very illustrative of what we were doing
so in this example we have like an aquatic ecosystem so it's almost like a gamified water savings
and so here we kind of see your water savings tracker and if the family met their goal for the month or the week
then you know this fish meets his mate and you know if you meet it again they
have some little guppies or whatever you call baby fish here and you know maybe you get a windmill in
there at some point you know it becomes more of a hipster aquarium i don't know so and it's also
touch sensitive kids really like this one that we tested with some families another one here is what we call rain
flow and this one was really trying to get out more of you want to let people understand what's the underlying activity
that's tied to their water use because actually we did surveys with people um people are really poor at
understanding the top areas that they use water in their homes there's three areas that are the most
common and we found that most people get at least one of those areas wrong and if not two
and so letting them really understand for what activities they're using water might help them better in this one we can kind
of see you know it's like showering versus toileting versus washing dishes or washing clothes
and you might have goals for those things and if you go over your goal something bad happens so here again
we've sped it up over time this design also had the weather and the date and time and some news headlines
the idea being there's reasons you would want to glance at it regularly you know in your home during the day so that you would start
to understand this information and again this one was on a touch screen so it had this nice
little animation and here we see for toileting we go over the goal and it eventually
overflows okay now the next step in this research
would really be to deploy it in homes for multiple months and have some kind
of control and have some great uh ground truth to understand whether we are affecting the behavior this didn't get
done yet john got his phd moved off to be a professor so we need to still do that and that's really important you know for
example i won't say my kids because i said that in my last talk and they got really mad they watched it on tv
some kids might think hey let's flush the toilet a lot to see that display come out
so maybe this actually this design actually does the opposite of what you want so you really
need to actually test these kind of things in the field for extended periods and see if you get the behavior change and then even
further we need to you as a field understand what happens when you take them away do have we change people's behavior or do
you need these things ongoing those are things the field hasn't even gotten the right methods to do well
people in behavioral psychology have done some of this but in hci and cs and ubicomp you know most people say that's too much
for a dissertation or too much work and we're still trying to figure out how do you make these kinds of studies easier to pull off we've also worked
in transportation because a large amount of your energy usage is in personal
transportation so an earlier project we did was called ub green john uh led the authorship of this those
several people including my colleagues at carnegie mellon led by jennifer minkoff and students and the idea here was can we sense your
transportation behavior on your phone and using the background screen of the phone give you feedback when your
transportation was green and try to kind of re encourage you to do those good behaviors
so as you went through your week you would see what your most recent transportation mode was and these leaves would grow
across this tree and eventually these flowers would bloom and at the bottom we also tried to tie
these other values that people felt were even more important than being green for example saving money being calm getting exercise
or being able to do something else while commuting um so in this case when you carpooled
you saved money and when you take the bus here maybe it's depending which bus you're on i
know some people's buses aren't very calm but you know for example the bus over the bay bridge versus driving i'd say
the bus is calmer or be able to read and so then if you met your goal for the week
in this interface design we had these um apples or fruit appear
and we actually had another interface design that the folks from cmu were really pushing because they had some theories about how
people bonded with animals it would lead to more behavior change so there was this other version here
where we had this polar scene and the more green you were the polar scene became healthier and healthier and that
the ice grew and there were more polar bears and they had polar bear babies and fish and stuff like that and then if you met your
goal here the northern lights came out okay and that's what happened um now
there were some surprising results in the experiments that we ran for this we kind of thought those ambient
displays you know that that graphics you just saw there were just really kind of tell you what you
were doing and give you information so you would be self-aware of what your behavior was
so we ran a pilot study all this was four weeks long and there were 12 people across two cities
for behavior change this is really a pilot you're really gonna be looking at something at least three to six months long with
that many people or more so this was kind of shake it out study so you know there's some informal
results several people wanted to keep running it that's always good with research software if somebody wants to run it on your
crappy old phone like you saw on that that thing that's a good sign we saw some behavior change i think some
of our participants were a little too green already especially those seattle people though we have people in pittsburgh
who are like driving three quarters of a mile to their friend's house and they said i'm not going to do that anymore so we
maybe helped the pittsburghers you know eric you might be able to confirm my theories there
the thing that i think was the most interesting research result which was less related to this particular problem was people
describe this in the interviews as oh i'd show the story to my wife or somebody at work said
hey what's going on with your polar bear or what does the tree look like now they almost thought of it as a game in
some ways and to me it was like what game it's just a you know display and we had some leaves you know but people
even with this very simple graphics were seeing this like a story and this really led me to believe that
using these kind of really simple stories for these behavior change applications could be a way to drive long-term
engagement because i think one of the problems that if you build these type of systems to deal with is kind of a novelty effect
it kind of seems cool at first but then you're sick of it but you can imagine authoring simple stories like this that people stay
engaged to kind of see what happens and then maybe you subscribe to a news story or maybe even have end user contributed
stories they're pretty easy to author that people could subscribe to just by getting a theme and not knowing what's
going to happen so surprising people were fairly engaged with what i thought was a fairly simplistic
story so i think we can use that in a lot of other places another issue in this behavior change
area is cultural and this is why i say you know it's important to understand different cultures
a lot of the behavior change work we've done in health and environment and i'll show you some health stuff in a minute
is based on a lot of psychology literature and other literature bj fogg here has done a lot of work here
at stanford and a lot of this stuff says you should stay fairly positive in the feedback that you give people and if you
give a lot of negative feedback people are going to stop using your system i was
in beijing only for a couple of months and i went to a seminar at microsoft and a japanese researcher
came in and he had a bunch of interfaces that looked really similar to what we had built and i was like these guys are copying our work what is
this stuff and he didn't know who i was and he said now we've seen a lot of this work at
intel in seattle and university of washington and they have all this positive feedback and he said we have negative
feedback because everyone knows in asia you need negative feedback okay and i i i was like huh do do you
have some evidence of that is there some literature or paper or something he said no but everyone knows
and they didn't actually test their stuff so we don't know but to me that was like oh that's a cool
research question is there a cultural difference in this type of feedback so we started
one project there that i would say is not definitive in answering this question but leads us
to have some information on it we did an online study with 180 chinese americans
and in this study they first had to fill out a standard carbon calculator talking about their home and their lifestyle and
their transportation needs and then they got some feedback from the system on how they were doing
and we manipulated that feedback in a careful way some people getting positive and need
feedback and then they had to make pledges about what changes they would make in their life and there were
suggestions that they could grab from this thing to do that and then they reported back later on which
changes they made in their lives and these steps happened over several weeks they weren't all at the same time
so some flaws in this study are it's a self-report study there's no ground truth for us to know what's true
but there are some interesting things so we thought feedback that was positive would be best based on everything we knew
it was really interesting for the chinese participants negative feedback had the bit led to the
biggest change in pro-environmental behavior okay statistically significant difference for the americans
positive feedback was bigger but i don't know if it's true it wasn't statistical difference there
in terms of you know we could look at the results and say you know you aren't doing as well as
other people in in the same kind of have same size home as you do and things like this so
how we couched how we told them what their performance was when they did the carbon calculator
simply that statement how we stated it being positive or negative okay and so we were able to control how
we did that to half the people so again i don't feel like this results definitive but it's kind of like
i think there's something there and so again the next step would be for example if we were doing our water display
uh deployment it would be interesting to do it in china versus the us and also manipulate this variable and
see when we have ground truth does that hold maybe it doesn't hold over long periods of time you know maybe
too much negative will get you to not want to use the system we're not sure of that this is again one-time use self-report
so there's some issues but it's interesting to see at least on the surface that there was some kind of difference between these
uh sets of people so culture may determine how to give feedback in these kind of behavior change
situations and it certainly shouldn't be ignored it seems important to consider the next area i want to kind of
describe about bounce is really balanced between people and their own bodies
and balance between exercise and food and things like this what you're seeing here is not a map of
what states voted which way last week but this is actually data from the center for disease control
and what it's showing is the body mass index being greater than 30. 30 means
clinically obese that's when we start to get a lot of correlated health issues diabetes heart disease etc for folks so
this is one they really care about and what we see is in 1990 most of the states are a dark green or slightly
lighter green meaning dark green less than 10 percent of the population of that state had bmis a great greater than 30 and
then the other states were 10 to 15 percent of their population and the ones that are gray mean they didn't have data um for those states at
this time now what you're about to see i think won't be too surprising to people
what's surprising to me is kind of the speed of this so as we go through the 90s we see we get
some more yellowing in the states we start to see some light
oranges as we get to around 2000 we go colorado the place to live if you want to be
healthy you know all those bikers runners triathletes but even the coloradans can't keep up with this trend
so as we get through the 2000s we start to get those red states getting orange okay
and here's the latest data 2010 okay in 2010 you're looking at
12 states that have about a third of their population clinically obese um we have 24 states that have over a
quarter of their population and then you know the remaining our 14 states are 20 to 25
it's a lot and in fact um if you even look at just numbers of the population i think it's um over 50 percent are now in the
overweight which is the one category below this or obese so it's it's a big problem and i think most of
us knew it i think what was really interesting when i first saw these this animation myself was just how
quickly that happened in 20 years this just went crazy like this and there's a lot of
different explanations having to do with you know more of a car culture or subsidized
corn you know corn sugar uh video games and people feeling less comfortable with their kids
playing outside there's all these things and it's probably some combination of these things together
but what we're looking at is an epidemic it's an obesity epidemic and again this is another problem that
feels to me worth us spending our time to work on and see what can we do about it versus
just coming up with the latest next cool game or something like that so you know what can we do from an hci and technology perspective
that might help people with this now again something was interesting to me living in china
china's developing world or you know in the middle of developed and developing was the us if you ever lived overseas
seems to export a lot of the things we're less proud of kind of bad food you'll see mcdonald's
kentucky fried chicken everywhere bad movies it's like they don't get the good films there are good ones they don't just go
and they get the big bad blockbusters surprising you know even this kind of obesity and overeating
more than seven percent of chinese children are obese second only in the us this comes from the chinese national task force and childhood
obesity statistics out of china you have to be skeptical a lot i'm not sure whether that's true but definitely you see it
across this burgeoning middle and upper class 400 million to 500 million people in china um still
leaving for 500 who are really poor but that's still a lot of people who are starting to have money they're starting to have these western
lifestyles and especially among boys culturally it was a tradition that you know you would
eat eat well to show your wealth and here we see this was from the people's daily it was
a weight loss camp with a kind of militaristic theme in uh shanghai that was in the paper
um so what would an audacious goal here be something like can we increase your
physical activity daily by 100 and we can work on the eating thing it's
its own hard problem i have another project on that but how about just physical activity okay
could we get those bmi levels back to 1990 might be the other way of stating this so one project
um that we did at intel and i'll ask this take this question in one second was called you be fit and we were really
trying to attack this issue what's your question how do you decide what's a good number
so increasing physical activity sounds a good idea how do you decide
what's a good goal or a good numbers question i don't have a very great way to do that and i actually thought about these in a
hard way in that i thought of what would be a hard goal to reach you know and does it seem like it'd be
significant you know with the energy one i could have said 20 and there's a lot of research backing us up that we know
how to do that right now so i actually wanted to try to push to what i wasn't sure i knew how to reach
in that one in this one i think i have seen numbers in terms of like what are
recommended daily step counts for people and what the averages are and it is kind of in this territory so i don't know if
that number is exactly what you want and we probably want to attack the food issue at the same time so it's again a
piece of the problem and it's meant to be kind of a goal that energizes people towards uh
achieving the research yeah gilbert similar question is do we have any idea
how people's exercise uh food consumption etc has changed over the
past 20 years um i mean i mean we i've read articles about how
you know people are more sedentary and people are eating more food but i can't give you like an exact twenty percent
number or anything like that um so this project called you be fit
um ended up being a phd dissertation for sonny consolvo who was a researcher at the intel lab but also pursuing her phd
at the university of washington in our information school and the basic idea here was
we felt with mobile computing technology advancing that by using sensing and machine
learning we could actually sense what physical activity people are engaged in in the real world
and by understanding what you're doing and feeding that information back to you so people could be more aware of what
they were doing because people really aren't aware of how much they exercise how much they walk how much they sit at their desk etc
we could help people meet their goals and change their behavior because often people already know they want to
do more they have a hard time sticking with what their plans are to change so in this system we had a wearable
device called the intel mobile sensing platform which had like 10 different sensors in it like accelerometers and light sensing
and it had its own processor and storage and bluetooth and then we had at the time the best
smartphone you could get which could barely run the graphics to you know keep that screen going so we
kind of separated the computing between these two devices you wear this one on your belt or something and then the information would be
transmitted to that phone so that's a basic architecture of how it worked and what you see on the
background of that phone is really the key idea here is what we call an ambient display so this garden would start out as just
green grass on sunday but as you engaged in physical activity these flowers would grow
and different flowers would appear depending on what you did so if you took a walk of 10 minutes or more a sunflower would appear if you did
aerobic activity like running biking stair machine elliptical trainer
then one of these orange flowers would appear and if you did strength training or stretching which you had to manually
enter because we didn't sense those the wider blue flowers would appear and so the idea is over your week your garden would grow
and if you met your goal for the week this butterfly would appear now the basic idea of the ambient
display is not that you look at the ambient display and say oh i walked three times and i ran four
times and i did this the idea was every time you pull out that phone to check the time
every time you pull out that phone to do an sms every time you pull out that phone to play a game you're seeing that
background screen first before you do something else and you're becoming more and more aware
of what your current activity is and in fact if late in the week it looked like this
you would feel fairly good about yourself going to meet my goals i'm doing well but if late in the week you know friday
let's say it looked like this you might feel boy i better take my gym bag today
or ride my bike to work instead of taking the bus and do something to kind of get towards your goals that was the basic idea
and i think this is an idea that many of the commercial products haven't really figured out yet and is one of
their problems you know like here's the fitbit everyone likes it it's got cool design and all this stuff but unless i think to
take it out and like go hey how many should i step today 6 000 steps doing okay i won't know
i have to think about it whereas the idea here is we're taking advantage of how much you use your phone for all
these other things to grab your attention but in a subtle way so
that's what that looked like from a ui point of design from the underlying technology we had this intel mobile
sensing platform it essentially is collecting all these different sensor readings at different frequencies and then
calculating features means medians all kinds of other simple mathematical
equations on them and then kind of coming up with an end best list of what activity you thought you were doing
at each instance okay so like you know three times a second it's inferring like walking walking
walking land days walking walking walking running running running standing walking walking walking and then this information was sent over
bluetooth to the phone which then on an application-wide basis could figure out
how to smooth that into the what it needed for that application so for example for for ub fit you know it might try to look
over longer periods what you're thinking it's doing on the other hand if i want to make an application that when i'm walking and looking at my phone
it makes things bigger so i can not run into light posts and things it might do that much quicker that
smoothing depending on your application again as i said we originally did this
this paper that tanzim choudhary led a lot of the machine learning work on this but this paper is like a physics paper or
old physics paper with like 20 people a lot a lot of engineering work
to go from machine learning algorithms that can be published in ai conferences and everyone says works
to making it really work on a real device and you know do real apps with it that
amount of engineering actually led to a whole other phd dissertation uh k or patel just finished on tools for
machine learning was how because of how hard that was now um we didn't think people are going to
want to wear these things we're playing the usual computer science trick of how do we throw some money at
something to predict the future by you know throwing things today that
eventually will be miniaturized and cheap and so only three or four years after we first started this we
took one of the first iphones and first android phones and one of the windows mobile phones at the time and rewrote the software and
showed you could do the activity inference on stock smartphone and the biggest
remaining thing at that point was can you do it without killing your battery and a bunch of researchers at
dartmouth and ucla and other places have now shown how to be smart about cycling the sensors to
actually do this so this technology could be in a good app today without killing your phone be able to understand
what physical activity you're doing more than just saying you're walking or running we really could tell a bunch of these activities now
there are some surprising results in the studies here sunny actually ran both a pilot study
similar to the one you saw there for ub green earlier that was three weeks 12 or 14 people really to work out the
kinks in the ui and also the activity inference and you know we found a bunch of bugs where
you know somebody was sitting in a chair at home and it said they were biking you know mislabeled training data things like
this but then for the phd dissertation she ran this much more long-term and careful study
